content.title: Kasbar, gastronomical epic into contemporary Morocco

introduction.small: In the Eaux-Vives neighbourhood, Kasbar is a trendy Moroccan restaurant in a modern and inviting setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kasbar, gastronomical epic into contemporary Morocco

paragraphs.text:
On Henri-Blanvalet Street, brimming with trendy addresses, Moroccan restaurant Kasbar stands out with stripped-down and airy decoration. A few ethnic items and colourful tapestries adorn the walls and a large yellow and green fresco reveals a geometrical pattern inspired by the moucharabieh, the famous architectural element traditionally found in Arab countries.
In the lobby, and under huge wicker lampshades, a mixologist perfects their craft behind an emerald-tiled covered counter – the colour also being used in the more intimate alcove with jade green velvet sofa benches. In this cosy atmosphere, the menu showcases shareable mezze. Vegetable briouats and beetroot hummus, Tanger style cromesquis croquetes served with watercress-avocado hummus and why not smoked eggplant zaalouk will take your palate on a delightful journey through Moroccan gastronomy.

Kasbar
Rue Henri-Blanvalet 23
1207 Geneva

+41 (0)22 736 27 46

kasbar-restaurant.com/en/

Menu: around 50 CHF

content.title: Raw eating at Bleu Carouge

introduction.small: In the Vieux Carouge neighbourhood of Geneva's outskirts, Bleu Carouge presents an innovative concept where every – almost – thing is to be eaten raw.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Raw eating at Bleu Carouge

paragraphs.text:
With its chic bistro look, high wooden tables and exposed stone walls, the tone is set. At Bleu Carouge, the leather sofa benches and the bar are blue, just like the napkins similar to our grandmothers' dish towels have blue ribbing, not mentioning the blue contents of your dish. The restaurant is an ode to raw food, as there is very little actual cooking, beef, fish and vegetable tartares and carpaccios being the norm. The contrast of very cool food comes from oven-baked potatoes covered in cream with herbs in lieu of regular fries. There, the flagship dish of bistro food is revisited with new flavours, like the Tahiti tuna tartare with coconut milk, ginger and coriander, or the Thai beef carpaccio with bean sprouts, lime and crunchy vegetables. A rare treat for raw food lovers.

Bleu Carouge
Rue Ancienne 23
1227 Carouge

+41 (0)22 320 30 30

www.bleucarouge.ch

Menu: around 51 CHF

content.title: Alpine and organic gastronomy at Neptune

introduction.small: On the left bank of the Rhône River in Geneva's Coulouvrenière neighbourhood, Le Neptune offers modernised Alpine cuisine sublimated by a restrained approach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alpine and organic gastronomy at Neptune

paragraphs.text:
In his Neptune restaurant, Nicolas Darnauguilhem only swears by local Genevan products. The chef plays the transparency card when it comes to suppliers, and he only uses fresh and organic ingredients. The establishment was even the first in town to be awarded “Homemade” distinction in French-speaking Switzerland.
Drawing inspiration from his great-grandmothers, Nicolas went back to the fundamental flavours and raw products of his region. He loves to prepare every single item served to customers, from the soy sauce to sourdough bread baked every morning, not forgetting hot pepper. In a refined and minimalist decor, contemporary art pieces are being lit by desk lamps fixed to the walls. A perfect setting for an ever changing and inspired cuisine, rethought every season. A natural yet sophisticated experience, to be enjoyed on the small terrace of the inner courtyard when the sun comes up.

Le Neptune
Rue de la Coulouvrenière 38
1204 Geneva

+41 (0)22 320 15 05

www.leneptune.ch/en/home-page ﻿

Menu: around 80 CHF

content.title: The Reserve, for a moment of pure well-being

introduction.small: With Lake Geneva as a backdrop, La Réserve hotel and spa is a must for a dream holiday just outside Geneva.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Reserve, for a moment of pure well-being

paragraphs.text:
Five kilometres from the city centre, you will discover a haven of peace in a four-hectare park on the shores of Lake Geneva. The Reserve welcomes you to a world of luxury, without ostentation.

Each of the 73 rooms and 29 suites has direct access to the pool and overlooks the gardens with Lake Geneva in the background. An African lodge theme is visible in the rooms thanks to the subtle decoration. Several materials are used —cotton, velvet, linen and silk—and the colours are reminiscent of African sunsets.

For lunch or dinner, the five restaurants offer many choices. The Tse Fung, under the direction of Frank Xu, revisits Chinese gastronomy by playing with textures, the chef of Loti, Virginie Basselot, focuses on her Norman origins and prepares a succulent pan-fried cod with lemon balm butter served on a bed of tapioca. Finally, the highlight of your stay will take place at the Nescens spa, where a team of therapists provides exceptional treatments to restore total well-being.

La Réserve
301, route de Lausanne
1293 Bellevue
Geneva

+41 (0)22 959 59 59

www.lareserve.ch

Rooms: from 553 CHF

content.title: The Globe of Science and Innovation of the European Council for Nuclear Research (CERN)

introduction.small: This immense wooden globe, a metaphor for the Earth and its future, hides within it the secrets of particle physics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Globe of Science and Innovation of the European Council for Nuclear Research (CERN)

paragraphs.text:
Originally designed for the 2002 Swiss National Exhibition, the Globe of Science and Innovation is now the starting point for visits of CERN (European Council for Nuclear Research), the largest particle-physics research centre in the world.

The Globe, 27 meters high and 40 meters in diameter, is a symbol of sustainable development and represents the Earth. Since wood is the most environmentally friendly material, spruce, pine and larch were chosen for its construction.

Inside, the ‘Universe of Particles' exhibition traces the history of atoms back to the Big Bang. You will discover where they come from and how they function. You will also understand how the particle accelerator works— an important tool for physicists. An exciting adventure in the world of the infinitely small.

At the entrance of the Globe, pause before Gayle Hermick's sculpture, ‘Peregrinations to Infinity'. This steel ribbon retraces the chronology of the various discoveries of physics that have marked history

Globe de la science et de l'innovation
385 route de Meyrin
1211 Genève

+41 (0)22 767 76 76

visit.cern/globe

content.title: Le Flacon pours its magic into the kitchen

introduction.small: Skilfully prepared seasonal fare and a welcoming atmosphere make Le Flacon one of the most popular tables in Geneva.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Flacon pours its magic into the kitchen

paragraphs.text:
In the charming town of Carouge, with its small coloured buildings and unique shops, Le Flacon is ideally located amid a profusion of signs in the charming and animated Sardinian quarter. The contemporary rustic style of the restaurant's wood and stone walls sets the tone for chef Yoann Caloué's cooking (one Michelin star and 15/20 Gault Millau points).

The food at Le Flacon derives its textures and flavours from the seasonal produce and the chef's talent and inspiration. The ingredients are carefully selected quince pulp, Colonnata bacon, nasturtium leaves and masterfully transformed into works of art. The open kitchen contributes to the great atmosphere, which is a mix of friendly and trendy.

The wait staff is welcoming, helpfully explaining each of the dishes that make up this exceptional cuisine.

Le Flacon
Rue Vautier 45
1227 Carouge

+41 (0)22 342 15 20

www.leflacon.ch

Menu: around 75 CHF

content.title: Brasserie des Halles de l'Île: a place on the water

introduction.small: At the decidedly urban yet idyllic Les Halles de l'Île, sample local wines as the Rhône river flows by.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brasserie des Halles de l'Île: a place on the water

paragraphs.text:
With its lounge atmosphere in a long city-centre building that juts out over the Rhône, this brasserie is accessed via the bridge from the island and a courtyard whose patio is one of the liveliest places to be in summer.

With large windows opening on to the river, the setting is exceptional. The interior is a contemporary nod to the building's industrial past. With its stainless steel bar echoing the building's oblong shape, the lounge is the perfect place for a relaxing after-work drink or pre-dinner apero.

The house offers a good selection of wines, including local ones. The Brasserie des Halles de l'Île is also developing a music scene, with DJ sessions, dancing on Sundays and Wednesdays, and live jazz and blues. All with a great view!

Brasserie des Halles de l'Île
Place de l'Île 1
1201 Geneva

+41 (0)22 311 08 88

www.brasseriedeshallesdelile.ch

Menu: around 40 CHF

content.title: Chez Quartier: cute and good!

introduction.small: Let yourself be swept away by this peerless tea salon, which is a pleasure for both the palate and the eyes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Quartier: cute and good!

paragraphs.text:
Unlike other establishments in the sober Voltaire neighbourhood, this pink tea salon jumps out at you. Porcelain, antique chocolate boxes, and miniature carriages joyfully decorate these ‘English' premises, which are quite unlike any other in Geneva. Pies, pastries, and other delicacies are all prepared with care, and taste just like home made. There is also honey from local producers on offer.

A little off the beaten tourist track, this is a popular address for the Genevois, who like to come here early in the morning or stay and chat in the courtyard. Snack on sandwiches and vegetarian pies throughout the day. And there is a subtle selection of fine teas for fans of tea time.

Another interesting aspect: you can serve yourself as if you were at home, making Chez Quartier unusually user-friendly.

Chez Quartier
Rue Voltaire 24
1203 Geneva

+41 (0)22 344 53 21

Menu: around 15 CHF

content.title: Chamonix: the grand spectacle of nature

introduction.small: Summer or winter, the resort abounds with treasures, to the delight of mountaineering enthusiasts and nature lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chamonix: the grand spectacle of nature

paragraphs.text:
Just over an hour from Geneva, Chamonix Valley, dominated by the legendary Mont Blanc, is a getaway destination. You feel the intensity of the small affluent town of Chamonix the moment you arrive. Mont Blanc and its towering 4,810 metres of rock, snow, and ice requires a certain state of mind: a love and respect of the mountains and its ethics.

Travel up to the higher altitudes via the lift or by climbing aboard the picturesque cog railway. The impressive Sea of Ice seems to quietly flow from the rocky mountains, the Aiguille du Midi towers over a seeming void, the Bossons glacier is blindingly beautiful. Walking buffs will be happy to explore mountain lakes, gems between heaven and earth, or venture on hiking trails redolent with the scent of fir trees.

Those who wish to take home a souvenir will find much to celebrate in Chamonix's wide variety of shops, prestigious brands, art galleries, and artisanal workshops that line the pedestrian streets of this ski resort.

Chamonix Tourism Office
85 Place du Triangle de l'Amitié
74400 Chamonix-Mont-Blanc

+33 (0)4 50 53 00 24

www.chamonix.com

content.title: Café Restaurant du Parc des Bastions: enchanting

introduction.small: A delicate cuisine that takes you back in time, in the heart of the historic Parc des Bastions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café Restaurant du Parc des Bastions: enchanting

paragraphs.text:
Full of rustic, authentic charm, the Café Restaurant du Parc des Bastions is housed in a old glassed-in kiosk. Around you, the elegant park stretches to the horizon. In summer, the terrace occupies the romantic promenade des Bastions in the shade of chestnut trees; in winter, a small lit-up ice rink animates the square with its echoes of yesteryear.

Between tradition and passion, the menu boldly follows the seasons, mixing flavours in sometimes unexpected compositions, such as whitefish fillets with artichokes and olives, beef with parmesan shavings, and truffled sea bream. This renowned table also serves local specialties. It is an opportunity to taste, for example, the Geneva longeole sausage with lentils.

Its big Sunday brunches are an institution in this city. The tables overflow with quality products like jams, various breads, fish, meats, cold cuts, fruits, cakes, etc. No need to hurry: time here is suspended.

Café Restaurant du Parc des Bastions
Promenade des Bastions 1
1204 Geneva

+41 (0)22 310 86 66

www.bastions.ch

Menu: around 30 CHF

content.title: Hotel des Horlogers: a nod to the watchmaking tradition

introduction.small: Humour and imagination come together in this original establishment, where in-watch mechanisms are the decorative concept.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel des Horlogers: a nod to the watchmaking tradition

paragraphs.text:
It is no coincidence that the Hotel des Horlogers is situated in the town of Plan-les-Ouates: this is where the major Swiss watch manufacturers are. Which is why the hotel came up with the fun idea of an immersive stay 'inside' a watch mechanism.

There are hundreds of period objects displayed cheek to jowl in the reception area, and the walls are covered with antique mechanism prints. The 32 rooms are humorously numbered from 10:00 a.m. to 3:45 p.m. Decorated in red and white, the rooms are comfortable and sober. The breakfast buffet is generously stocked with fresh produce delivered daily, and the hot chocolate comes from a local artisan.

Located 15 minutes by public transport from downtown, this surprising little hotel is a perfect choice for those seeking excellent value for money in Geneva.

Hôtel des Horlogers
Route de Saint-Julien 135
1228 Plan-les-Ouates

+41 (0)22 884 08 33

www.horlogers-ge.ch

Rooms: from 126 CHF

content.title: The Patek Philippe Museum: watchmaking excellence and rarity

introduction.small: The Patek Philippe Museum illustrates the history of watchmaking in Geneva, and displays spectacular treasures from the Patek Philippe collection.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Patek Philippe Museum: watchmaking excellence and rarity

paragraphs.text:
Geneva watchmaking, which is world-renowned, grew out of the city's goldsmith industry in the 13th century. Watchmaking was further fuelled by the Calvinist Reformation in the 16th century, which prohibited luxury and pomp, thereby forcing goldsmiths to learn another trade. By the 17th century, Geneva's expertise and excellence in watchmaking was well established and its reputation spread throughout Europe.

The Patek Philippe Museum showcases the exceptional Patek Philippe collection, whose pieces go back to 1845. You can admire precision-cut enamels, which are true works of miniature art, and let yourself be dazzled by the technical prowess of complicated watches.Among them is the famous ‘Marie Antoinette' timepiece. The French queen's pocket watch is the most complicated mechanism ever created.

A true ‘temple of time', the museum holds unimaginable treasures like musical automata and fancy watches, the variety of forms and eccentricity of which will not cease to amaze you. The unparalleled ingenuity and talent displayed show why Geneva is at the very forefront in the world of watchmaking.

Patek Philippe Museum
Rue des Vieux Grenadiers 7
1205 Geneva

+41 (0)22 807 09 10

www.patekmuseum.com

content.title: La Cour des Augustins: a decidedly urban hotel

introduction.small: The unique Cour des Augustins offers a stay amid contemporary works of art and design.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cour des Augustins: a decidedly urban hotel

paragraphs.text:
In a colourful alleyway in the Plainpalais district, La Cour des Augustins is a true curiosity. Resolutely urban, the hotel differentiates itself from other places in Geneva's ‘Latin Quarter', by its design aesthetic and its hyped reputation. Composed of 16 rooms and 24 suites combining comfort and technology, this blue-shuttered establishment consists of two buildings connected by an intimate courtyard.

The architectural concept by Swiss designer Philippe Cramer is based on the personalisation and diversity of spaces. Subtly blending modernity and classicism, each room has its own atmosphere and unique style, but is unified by contemporary designer furniture and decorative objects.

Always a place of discovery, the Cour des Augustins presents a beautiful collection of African art that gives a vibrant dimension to the hotel. Discreetly hidden away is a ‘wellness' area with a sauna and steam room, which makes this hotel as comfortable as it is practical.

La Cour des Augustins
Rue Jean-Violette 15
1205 Geneva

+41 22 322 21 00

www.lacourdesaugustins.com

Rooms: from 183 CHF

content.title: The Reformation: a wall of historical significance

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Reformation: a wall of historical significance

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible to visit Geneva without seeing its most famous landmark: the Mur des Réformateurs, or Reformation Wall. Measuring 100 metres in length and five metres in height, it is as imposing visually as it was politically when it was erected.

Known as ‘Protestant Rome, the little republic of Geneva became the headquarters of Calvinism the most rigorous form of Protestantism in the 16th century. The Reformation Wall pays tribute to this period during which Calvinism marked the town and became embedded into its citizens' way of life. The statues of four of the founding fathers of the Reformation Farel, Calvin, Beza, and Knox rest against the old city walls, rising majestically in the elegant Parc des Bastions. Radiant in broad daylight and illuminated at night (Geneva's motto, ‘Post Tenebras Lux', meaning ‘After darkness, light', is not for nothing), the whole ensemble is protected by a water basin, recalling the moat of the ancient fortifications.

The impressively rigorous statuary is the work of French sculptors Paul Landowski and Henri Bouchard. Bouchard also sculpted Les Quatres Races facing the Botanical Garden and Christ the Redeemer at the peak of the Corcovado mountain in Rio de Janeiro.

Mur des Réformateurs
Promenade des Bastions, in the Parc des Bastions
1204 Geneva

+41 (0)22 909 70 00

content.title: Nest Living: a nest away from the nest

introduction.small: ‘Home away from home' is the motto of Nest Living, whose apartments are the next best thing to being at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nest Living: a nest away from the nest

paragraphs.text:
Nest Living offers an alternative to hotels for medium-term stays in Geneva. In a magnificent 18th-century building, comfortable and tastefully decorated apartments await visitors who want to experience the city as if they were at home.

With a choice of views over the rooftops of the old town or the inner courtyard, the accommodation is spacious and bright. Ranging from small studios to large two-bedroom apartments, these nests of contemporary architecture are furnished with great care, combining elegant design and customised furniture.

The location is ideal, with restaurants, bars, galleries, shops and tourist attractions nearby. The hotel staff is dynamic and discreet, ready to provide you with maps, guides, and tips. They will even fill your fridge and deliver wine if you want. A perfect pied-a-terre in which you don't have to take care of anything so you can just have fun!

Nest Living
12-14 rue Étienne-Dumont
1204 Geneva

+41 22 518 02 82

www.nest-geneva.ch

Rooms: from 228 CHF

content.title: Le Jour & La Nuit: the privileges of a mansion stay

introduction.small: A charming bed and breakfast with a warm welcome for each of its guests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Jour & La Nuit: the privileges of a mansion stay

paragraphs.text:
Two bedrooms and a suite in this 20th century family home are tastefully and originally decorated in picturesque themes like ‘lake', ‘meadow', and ‘mountain'. The rooms boast designer furniture and noble materials, but there are also humorous touches, like a wooden sled that doubles as a coffee table in the ‘Mountain side' room.

At the heart of a beautifully maintained garden, Le Jour & La Nuit is a peaceful 15 minutes from the city centre. Your nights will be gentle (special attention was paid to ensure quality of sleep) and days filled with warmth, starting with an elegant breakfast delivered to your door you can enjoy it in the privacy of your bedroom.

A kitchen is also at your disposal, as well as garden and barbecue facilities in summer. You will be treated with warmth, personalised attention, and discretion, making this place an exceptional stopover.

Le Jour & La Nuit
Avenue du Mervelet 8
1209 Geneva

+41 (0)79 214 73 87

www.lejouretlanuit-bnb.com

Rooms: from 224 CHF

content.title: Imagine the birth of Frankenstein in the Pré Byron

introduction.small: Unparalleled views of the city and a touch of mystery: the Pré Byron is the place where ‘Frankenstein' sprang from the pen of Mary Shelley.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Imagine the birth of Frankenstein in the Pré Byron

paragraphs.text:
Located on the Cologny hillside, not far from the city centre, the Pré Byron offers breathtaking views of Geneva: opposite the dark slopes of the Jura, Lake Geneva unfolds in all its majesty, its colour varying according to the light of the sky.

The classical facades of the bay and the Palais des Nations form a striking contrast to the immensity of nature. This magical place is also one of historical literary relevance: it is the ‘birthplace' of Frankenstein. In 1816, that rainy ‘year without summer'.

Mary Shelley stayed with Lord Byron at Villa Diodati, right next to the Pré. Her novel, Frankenstein, became a success the world over and Shelley's monstrous creature is part of the collective imagination today. The Pré Byron is a place to relax, contemplate life, and to watch the Bol d'Or, the famous regatta held on Lake Geneva every year in June.

Pré Byron
Chemin de Ruth 9
1223 Cologny

content.title: Hotel Les Armures: a treasure of the 17th century

introduction.small: The soul and comfortable life of a former private mansion transformed into a luxury hotel full of charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Les Armures: a treasure of the 17th century

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the old city with its cobbled streets, Les Armures enjoys a privileged location and offers lovers of authenticity exceptional surroundings. Sheltered from the teeming hustle and bustle of the streets, the 32 beautifully restored rooms and suites have attracted many celebrities.

If wood and old stones contribute to its historical spirit and romantic atmosphere, modern taste inspires its unique five-star decoration. Contrasting yet elegant materials and soft colours seduce the senses and amaze Epicureans. The hotel is welcoming, warm, and personal. Breakfast, served in the 17th century hall, favours balanced dishes and local products.

If you wish to discover more local delights in a casual atmosphere, the hotel-restaurant is renowned for its variety of cheese fondues classic, or with herbs, tomatoes, mushrooms, etc.

Hôtel Les Armures
Rue Puits-Saint-Pierre 1
1204 Geneva

+41 22 310 91 72

www.hotel-les-armures.ch

Rooms: from 381 CHF

content.title: The Ninth Art… invented by a Genevan

introduction.small: Surrounded by beautiful mansions, Toepffer Square in the Les Tranchées district reminds us that the comic strip originated in Geneva.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ninth Art… invented by a Genevan

paragraphs.text:
Did you know that the comic strip was born in Geneva? Rodolphe Toepffer, a teacher with innovative methods, was the first to produce them: he used to take his students on long school-excursion study trips, which he recounted with verve in illustrated books. Encouraged by Goethe, who was amazed by the humour and novelty of the process, Toepffer produced numerous masterpieces.

A square and a sculpture are dedicated to him in the luxurious Les Tranchées district, which has remarkable buildings dating back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The residential sector is a striking symbol of the history of modern Geneva: it was the first to be built beyond the fortifications that encircled the upper town at the time.

The orthogonal grid of streets allowed the construction of luxurious mansions. The Fondation Baur, Musée des Arts d'Extrême-Orient (Baur Foundation, Far East Art Museum), is housed in one of the residences of the area. Visit and view the beautiful Imperial Japanese ceramics on display.

La Fondation Baur, Musée des Arts d'Extrême-Orient
Rue Munier-Romilly 8
Square Toepffer
Les Tranchées district
1206 Geneva

+41 (0)22 704 32 82

www.fondationbaur.ch/en/home-page

content.title: The Pâquis Baths: a local favourite

introduction.small: Enjoy beautiful days in the middle of Lake Geneva while keeping your feet firmly on the ground.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pâquis Baths: a local favourite

paragraphs.text:
The one-of-a-kind Pâquis Baths is a coveted spot in Geneva, perfect for relaxing, sunbathing, swimming, and having a massage. Built out of wood in 1872, expanded in 1889 with a construction on stilts, the Pâquis Baths were rebuilt in reinforced concrete in 1932. Its architectural simplicity gives the site a striking timelessness. Located at the end of a pier, it places the visitor in the middle of the lake, giving the impression that you are sailing or perpetually traveling.

On one hand, you can enjoy the view of the city and its fountain; on the other, your gaze is lost in the distance, along the shores of Lake Geneva. Saunas, Turkish baths, and steam baths vary the pleasures, making the baths a place with a clientele of faithful regulars. The restaurant serves simple, fresh meals in summer, and cheese fondues in winter, always in a friendly atmosphere.

Early risers will enjoy the amazing ‘musical dawn concerts' during the summer. Autumn gives way to poetry readings the first and third Saturdays of the month. Let yourself be enchanted throughout the year!

Bains des Pâquis
Quai du Mont-Blanc 30
1201 Geneva

+41 (0)22 732 29 74

www.bains-des-paquis.ch

content.title: The Museum of Ethnography: the zenith of contemporary art

introduction.small: Newly renovated, this museum, located in Geneva's trendy contemporary art neighbourhood, symbolises the crossroads of cultures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of Ethnography: the zenith of contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
Contemporary art has a vibrant scene in Geneva, backed by fashionable galleries and flagship institutions: MAMCO (Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art), the Contemporary Art Centre, the Photography Centre and the Municipal Contemporary Art Fund. The contemporary scene, concentrated around Rue des Bains, has become a hub of bubbling creativity.

The contrast with the working-class Plainpalais neighbourhood is striking and gives a distinctively trendy feel to this part of the city. The Ethnographic Museum, renovated in 2014, is a new symbol in this ever-changing landscape. It is distinguished by its slanted facade of metal diamond-shaped panels that reflect the moods of the sky, and was designed by architects Marco Graber and Thomas Pulver.

The museum identifies and presents more than a 1,000 peoples and their cultures.Three times a year, the museum, together with the art establishments on the Rue des Bains, organises a festive open house called the Nuit des Bains, an event where one goes to see and be seen.

Musée d'ethnographie de Genève (MEG)
Boulevard Carl Vogt 65-67
1205 Geneva

+41 (0)22 418 45 50

www.meg-geneve.ch

content.title: The Botanical Garden: cultivation and culture

introduction.small: A perfect place to stroll in any season, the Botanical Garden showcases plant abundance in all its glory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Botanical Garden: cultivation and culture

paragraphs.text:
The Conservatory and Botanical Garden is a garden of paradise that dates back to 1904. It extends over an area of ​​28 hectares close to Lake Geneva and the UN. It is home to 14,000 varieties from around the world. Winding paths, lush and colourful, take the flâneur from one thematic area to another—from rock to massifs of protected plants, medicinal plants, and palm trees.

This outdoor museum is both educational and enchanting. Filled with plants of all shapes and scents, as well as animals and insects, the Botanical Garden makes your senses come alive.

Founded by the famous botanist Augustin Pyramus de Candolle in what is now Bastions Park in 1817, the Botanical Garden retains the same naturalist spirit that prevailed in the 19th century.

Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques
Chemin de l'Impératrice 1
1292 Chambésy-Geneva

+41 (0)22 418 51 00

www.cjb-geneve.ch

content.title: Bistrot La Fabrique: a manufacturer of gastronomic dreams

introduction.small: Despite its relaxed atmosphere, Bistrot La Fabrique doesn't skimp on gourmet food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bistrot La Fabrique: a manufacturer of gastronomic dreams

paragraphs.text:
With its industrial and epicurean atmosphere where there is ‘no fuss or prohibitions' as the slogan goes La Fabrique is the place for trendy tapas snacking in Geneva. The wine menu (organic) is elaborate and selection of craft beers are carefully chosen by the owner.

Everybody composes their own plate, which becomes a gustatory stroll through Britain, Spain, Italy, Switzerland, and Japan. The suggestions are original and varied, and the brasserie is open from morning until night. The highlight is the chopped beef tartare finely seasoned according to taste.

This has quickly become the place to be in Geneva for those who like a relaxing, warm, urban style.

Bistrot La Fabrique
Rue Micheli-du-Crest 2
1205 Geneva

+41 (0)22 320 50 70

www.lafab.ch

Menu: around 35 CHF

content.title: Hotel Mon Repos: pleasure and peace of mind

introduction.small: In picturesque green surroundings, the Hotel Mon Repos strives to provide relaxation and tranquillity to its guests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Mon Repos: pleasure and peace of mind

paragraphs.text:
Across from the splendid park of La Perle du Lac, Hotel Mon Repos is conveniently located away from the bustle of the neighbouring district of Pâquis, and provides relaxation and serenity. Behind the elegant, red-curtained facade, 79 comfortable rooms have been remodelled in soothing tones. The intimate bar offers a small menu based on fresh and seasonal products. The atmosphere is cosy and the staff attentive and friendly. This aptly named hotel is also a popular stopover for business travellers. Fully furnished residential apartments offer everything you need to feel perfectly at home.

Hôtel Mon Repos
Rue de Lausanne 131
1202 Geneva

+41 (0)22 909 39 09

www.hotelmonrepos.ch

Rooms: from 208 CHF

content.title: The Esplanade of Nations: a place of commitment

introduction.small: The Esplanade of Nations is a reminder of the continual struggle of international organisations for a better and more just world. A walk here is an experience in itself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Esplanade of Nations: a place of commitment

paragraphs.text:
The esplanade des Nations, or Esplanade of Nations, constructed in 2007, is composed of strips of granite from UN member countries, with ‘international' soil alternating with ‘neutral' slabs of the same grey concrete used for sidewalks in Geneva. A colossal fountain with 84 water jets echoes the international organisations present in the area. Jets playfully go on and off to accommodate the frequent gatherings here.

A sculpture called Broken Chair dominates the square from a height of 12 metres. At the behest of Handicap International, it was made in 1997 by sculptor Daniel Berset to convince nations to sign the convention banning landmines.

Resting on three legs with a fourth broken halfway up, it vibrantly evokes the fate of victims of landmines. The two walls that encircle the entrance of the Palais are decorated with designs on the theme of peace, made in 2009 and 2012 by the artist Hans Erni. The Esplanade of Nations immerses you viscerally in the heart of a forest of symbols.

L'esplanade des Nations
Place des Nations, facing the UN
1202 Geneva

content.title: The United Nations: a palace as grand as Versailles

introduction.small: The ineluctable Palace of Nations dominates the area. Through its monumentality and the sheer multitude of activities that take place under its roof, it breathes special energy into the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The United Nations: a palace as grand as Versailles

paragraphs.text:
In 1919, Geneva was chosen as the head quarters of the League of Nations (LN). It was the first-ever intergovernmental organisation with a political vocation to be established at the heart of world diplomacy.

The need to build a ‘temple of peace' quickly became obvious. Several architects Carlo Broggi (Italy), Julien Flegenheimer (Switzerland), Camille Lefèvre and Henri-Paul Nénot (France), and Joseph Vago (Hungary) worked together on the project. The construction lasted from 1929 to 1937 and was the largest architectural project of its time in Europe. The building it gave birth to is as large as Versailles. The exterior of the complex, consisting of five buildings, is characterised by monumental Academicism; its interior, however, is decorated with outstanding works of art, reflecting the cultural diversity of the countries that made up the League.

The League of Nations stopped its activities with the Second World War. After its dissolution in 1946, the Palace became the European headquarters of the United Nations and, in 1966, the United Nations Office at Geneva (UNOG). Today, it is the venue for some 9,000 meetings yearly, making it the hub of global diplomatic activity.

Palais des Nations
14, avenue de la Paix
(entrance via the Pregny Gate, opposite the ICRC)
1202 Geneva

+41 (0)22 917 48 96

visit-gva@unog.ch
